instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-02016: What is 820-02016? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A2337: What is A2337? A2337 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Late 2020 M1 with EMC 3598, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-02016..
definitions.PPVOUT_LCDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_LCDBKLT? PPVOUT_LCDBKLT is the backlight power rail that is responsible for creating a backlight o nthe screen. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No backlight
threads.message:
Hello,

I got a MacBook Air 2020 M1 13i <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, logic board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, able to boot, and works properly if I plug an external monitor and close the lid.

However, there is no way to see anything on the macbook air's screen itself; it stays black.

I measured CP860, pin 1, it goes up to 357mV, then down to 352mV, and fluctuates in this range, instead of 48-50V as per the repair.wiki
The board is in its case, battery unplugged, bottom case obviously removed, lid open, and macbook upside down.
I did not find any short in the <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> area; CP860 to CP866; DP800; LP800.

I did the same measurement on CP860 but without the screen plugged in, and got the exact same values (357mV, then fluctuates from 352 to 357mV)

So, screen undetected. Owner said the screen stopped working suddenly while in use. 

Next step, test with a known good screen I assume? Will have to source that, as I usually work on older machines

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No backlight
threads.message:
Testing with known good LCD assembly is the best option.

First check <SIGNAL>AMR_LEFT</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>RIGHT_OR_ND_1V8</SIGNAL> signals, with lid open/close.
Also check <SIGNAL>LPDP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL> level, with LCD assembly connected.
